name: Job
shortDescription: The righteous sufferer who maintained faith through catastrophic loss - paradigm of patience and endurance that James invokes for suffering believers
longDescription: Job (Hebrew: Iyyov) is the central figure of the biblical Book of Job, one of the wisdom books of the Hebrew Bible. The narrative presents Job as a 'blameless and upright' man, 'one who feared God and turned away from evil' (Job 1:1) - the greatest man of all the East in wealth, family, and righteousness. When Satan challenges that Job's piety depends on prosperity, God permits Satan to strip away everything: his flocks, servants, children, and finally his health. Job sits among ashes, covered with boils, his wife urging him to 'curse God and die.' Three friends arrive to offer comfort but instead become accusers, insisting Job must have sinned secretly to deserve such punishment. Through 37 chapters of dialogue, Job maintains his innocence while wrestling with God's apparent injustice. He never curses God but demands an audience to plead his case. Finally, God answers from the whirlwind - not with explanations but with overwhelming questions revealing divine wisdom beyond human comprehension. Job repents 'in dust and ashes,' not of sin, but of presuming to understand God's ways. God rebukes the friends for speaking wrongly, commends Job for speaking rightly, and restores his fortunes twofold. The Epistle of James specifically invokes Job: 'You have heard of the patience (hypomone - steadfast endurance) of Job, and you have seen the purpose of the Lord, how the Lord is full of compassion and mercy' (James 5:11). Job stands as the biblical paradigm for suffering believers - one who endured terrible trials yet never abandoned faith in God's ultimate goodness.

etymology.meaning: Possibly 'Where is the (divine) father?' or 'persecuted one'
etymology.derivation: Etymology debated; may relate to 'ayab' (to be hostile) or be a non-Hebrew name
etymology.symbolicInterpretation: The name itself may embody his question: Where is God in suffering?

primaryLocation.significance: Job is explicitly not Israelite, suggesting wisdom transcends national boundaries

biography.characterDescription: Job 1:1 - 'blameless and upright, one who feared God and turned away from evil'
biography.status: Greatest of all the people of the East in wealth and righteousness

family.restoredFamily: Seven sons, three daughters - Jemimah, Keziah, and Keren-happuch (Job 42:13-14)

majorEvents.description: Satan (the Accuser) challenges Job's piety before God; God permits testing of Job's faith
In a single day: Sabeans steal oxen and donkeys, fire destroys sheep, Chaldeans take camels, wind collapses house killing all children
'Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return. The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.' In all this Job did not sin.
Satan afflicts Job with loathsome sores from head to foot; Job sits among ashes scraping himself with pottery
'Do you still hold fast your integrity? Curse God and die.' Job replies: 'Shall we receive good from God, and shall we not receive evil?' In all this Job did not sin with his lips.
Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar come to comfort Job; they sit with him in silence for seven days
Three cycles of speeches: friends insist suffering implies sin; Job maintains innocence while questioning God's justice
Young Elihu offers a different perspective - God uses suffering to teach and purify
God answers Job - not with explanations but overwhelming questions revealing divine wisdom and power beyond human comprehension
'I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees you; therefore I despise myself, and repent in dust and ashes.'
God rebukes the friends, commends Job, and restores his fortunes twofold. Job lives 140 more years, seeing four generations.

biography.legacy: Paradigm of faithful suffering - one who maintained integrity through catastrophic loss, wrestling honestly with God rather than offering false piety or abandoning faith

jamesReference.text: Behold, we count them happy which endure. Ye have heard of the patience of Job, and have seen the end of the Lord; that the Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy.
jamesReference.meaning: Not passive resignation but active endurance; steadfast perseverance under trial

whatJobEndured: Loss of all wealth - 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, 500 donkeys
Death of all ten children in a single day
Painful physical affliction covering his entire body
Wife's urging to 'curse God and die'
Friends' accusations that he must have sinned secretly
God's apparent silence through most of his suffering
Feeling abandoned by the God he had faithfully served
howJobEndured: Never cursed God despite Satan's expectation
Blessed God's name even in loss (Job 1:21)
Maintained his integrity against all pressure
Spoke honestly to God rather than offering false piety
Demanded a hearing rather than abandoning faith
Ultimately submitted to God's greater wisdom

jamesApplication.context: James 5:7-11 addresses suffering believers awaiting the Lord's return
jamesApplication.teaching: Like Job, believers should endure trials with patience, knowing God's purpose is compassion and mercy
jamesApplication.promise: Those who endure are 'blessed' (makarios) - the same beatitude language Jesus used

theodicy.friendsPosition: Retribution theology - suffering implies sin; if Job is suffering, he must have sinned
theodicy.jobsProtest: Maintains innocence while questioning God's justice; demands an audience with God
theodicy.godsAnswer: Neither explains nor justifies but reveals divine wisdom beyond human comprehension
theodicy.resolution: Trust in God's wisdom and goodness transcends human understanding of justice
theodicy.wisdomContribution: Challenges simplistic 'prosperity gospel' thinking; affirms faithful suffering as legitimate

righteousSufferer.description: Job as type of the innocent sufferer, anticipating Christ's passion
righteousSufferer.connection: Both are righteous, both suffer unjustly, both are ultimately vindicated

intercessor.description: Job prays for his friends; God accepts his intercession
intercessor.connection: Priestly role anticipating Christ as intercessor

redeemer.text: 'For I know that my Redeemer lives, and at the last he will stand upon the earth. And after my skin has been thus destroyed, yet in my flesh I shall see God.'
redeemer.significance: Anticipates resurrection hope and personal encounter with the living God

Wife's name given as Rahma in some traditions
Seven or eighteen years of affliction in various accounts
islamicTradition.sabr: Arabic term for patient endurance - a cardinal virtue in Islam exemplified by Ayyub
